Case-Study.name: Forest Macrogroups of the Americas: '1.A.1.Ea.134 - Caribbean Coastal Lowland Dry Forest EN (EN -- CR)'
Case-Study.Case-Study-Name: Forest Macrogroups of the Americas: '1.A.1.Ea.134 - Caribbean Coastal Lowland Dry Forest EN (EN -- CR)'

Assessment-Target.AT-description: The '1.A.1.Ea.134 - Caribbean Coastal Lowland Dry Forest' is a forest macrogroup belonging to the '1.A.1.Ea Caribbeo-Mesoamerican Dry Forest' division in the International Vegetation Classification system (Faber-Langendoen et al. 2014). It is considered here as a proxy for a forest ecosystem type in a regional assessment of forest ecosystems in the Americas.

Abiotic-environment.Summary: La media de las temperaturas anuales en el rango de región de bosque seco del Caribe de 23 ° C (74 ° F) en el norte hasta 26 ° C (77 ° F) en los Cayos Bajos. La precipitación ocurre principalmente de junio a octubre y va desde 1.650 mm a lo largo de la costa atlántica disminuyendo hacia el sur hasta menos de 1.000 mm en los Cayos Bajos (Gillespie 2006). La precipitación en el área de distribución de este bosque en Puerto Rico y en la mayor parte de las islas de Culebra y Vieques oscila 600-1100 mm por año (Brandeis et al. 2009), con dos estaciones secas suelos de piedra caliza de coral, suelos carbonatados húmicos, ferralítico rojo o suelos arenososGeología subyacente, suelos diferentes entre estas regiones, suelos son altamente orgánicos con desigual rango de espesor

Biotic-processes.Summary: Los bosques tienen baja estatura, de alta densidad de las pequeñas y medianas árboles, y tienen cubiertas de una capa sin árboles emergentes. El estrato herbáceo es escaso desarrollo o completamente ausente. La diversidad florística es bajo en comparación con los bosques más húmedos, y especies de alto predominio es común. La variación en el período de temporada seca, la topografía y el sustrato determinar las características específicas de las comunidades de vegetación en este macrogrupo ya que todos ellos tienen una gran importancia en los bosques secos como determinantes de la variación en la disponibilidad de agua. El sotobosque leñoso es en su mayoría de hoja perenne. El estrato herbáceo es escaso desarrollo o completamente ausente.Estos bosques tienden a tener un dosel denso que produce sombra más profunda, menos evaporación, y la más baja la temperatura del aire de la vegetación circundante Este sistema ecológico se produce como una banda estrecha de bosque de frondosas y matorrales. La vegetación se caracteriza por especies de madera dura con afinidades tropicalesVegetación se caracteriza por especies de madera dura con afinidades tropicales

Threat.Threat-description: Increasing human population can be a cause of loss of woodland distribution due to increase in resource use, expansion of infrastructure, and changes in land use. It is also indirectly associated to the spread of invasive species.
Elimination of tree cover.

Climate conditions are generally considered of great importance for the maintainance of forest vegetation and characteristic processes of several macrogroups, and were also incorporated in the process of macrogroup potential distribution modeling and validation (Bow et al. 2008; Josse et al. 2009)⁠. Thus we considered climate change as a plausible future threat of degradation of environmental conditions (Laurance & Williamson 2001; Tovar et al. 2013)⁠

⁠Defaunation is considered a large and pervasive threat to biodiversity, the loss of large vertebrates due to overexploitation has an impact in important biotic associations in ecosystems (Galetti & Dirzo 2013; Dirzo et al. 2014)⁠.

Conceptual-ecosystem-model.CEM-summary: A general conceptual model is presented graphically in Fig. S1. We include in this model the most important large scale threats to forest in the Americas: loss of forest cover due to agriculture and live stock expansion; defaunation due to hunting (or “empty forest syndrome”), structural and compositional changes due to selective logging and invasion of exotic species, changes in disturbance regimes due to land use practices and development and shifting climatic conditions due to climate change.

Distribution.Summary: Bsq. Seco de tierras bajas Este macrogrupo se encuentra en el sur de Florida, los Cayos de Florida, las Bahamas, Islas Caimán, Cuba, La Española, Jamaica, Islas de Sotavento, Puerto Rico, Trinidad y Tobago, y las Islas de Barlovento.Bsq. Seco de tierras bajas US/FloridaBsq. Seco de tierras bajas US/FloridaBsq. Seco de tierras bajas US/Florida
Distribution.Biogeographic-region: WWF ecoregion 'Trinidad and Tobago moist forests'
Global 200 ecoregion 'Southeastern conifer and broadleaf forests'

Collapse-definition.Spatial-collapse: As the tree growth form is the main structural element of any forest macrogroup, a forest macrogroup was assumed to collapse if the original woodland cover was completely replaced by a non-woodland cover, or if the tree-cover within its potential distribution declined to zero (criteria A and B).
Collapse-definition.Functional-collapse: For assessing environmental degradation under criterion C, we considered two different indicators. In the case of climate change, we assume that the ecosystem collapsed if the climatic conditions shifted from mostly suitable for the focus macrogroup, to mostly suitable to a different macrogroup. Additionally for flooded and swamp forest, we assumed ecosystem collapse if the amount of detected surface water within the potential distribution of the macrogroup declined to zero. For assessing disruption to biotic processes and interactions under criterion D we assumed that most of the fundamental processes and interactions disappeared with intensive use of woodlands under high population density. We also assumed that the ecosystem would collapse if the population of large mammals declined to less than 10% of their original population size.

Assessment-unit.name: global

Ecosystem-subset.name: Global
Ecosystem-subset.Subset-description: Regional or Continental-level assessment for the whole distribution of the '1.A.1.Ea.134 - Caribbean Coastal Lowland Dry Forest' macrogroup.

Assessment-unit.Rationale: According to the evaluated indicators the threshold for EN was reached for criteria. Uncertainty in the indicators suggests that the overall category can be in the range os EN -- CR.

Subcriterion.name: A1
Subcriterion.Rationale: The best estimate of the rate of recent change in woodland cover reached the threshold for EN for subcriterion A1. Uncertainty in this indicator suggests that the category for subcriterion A1 could be in the range of LC -- EN.

Subcriterion.name: A2b
Subcriterion.Rationale: The predicted future changes in tree cover was below the threshold for Vulnerable, and this unit is considered Least Concern under subcriterion A2b.

Subcriterion.name: A3
Subcriterion.Rationale: The best estimate of the rate of historical change in woodland cover reached the threshold for EN for subcriterion A3. Uncertainty in this indicator suggests that the category for subcriterion A3 could be in the range of VU -- CR.

Criterion.name: E
Criterion.Summary: No quantitative assessment of ecosystem collapse was performed for this assessment unit.

Case-Study.name: Forest Macrogroups of the Americas: '1.A.1.Ea.294 - Caribbean Dry Limestone Forest EN'
Case-Study.Case-Study-Name: Forest Macrogroups of the Americas: '1.A.1.Ea.294 - Caribbean Dry Limestone Forest EN'

Assessment-Target.AT-description: The '1.A.1.Ea.294 - Caribbean Dry Limestone Forest' is a forest macrogroup belonging to the '1.A.1.Ea Caribbeo-Mesoamerican Dry Forest' division in the International Vegetation Classification system (Faber-Langendoen et al. 2014). It is considered here as a proxy for a forest ecosystem type in a regional assessment of forest ecosystems in the Americas.

Abiotic-environment.Summary: Climas estacional con precipitación anual de 800 a 1500 mm. La estación seca puede durar de dos a varios meses. 1.- Suelos fértiles profundos en Valles y suelos poco profundos, rocosos, e infértiles en las cimas de mogotes y pendientes exhibiendo condiciones edáficas intermedios. Suelos más o menos erosionadas esqueléticos

Biotic-processes.Summary: Baja riqueza de especies pero con alto endemismo vegetal. Dosel algo abierto, conformado principalemnte por vegetación cauducilofia de 6 a 15 m de altura, con árboles emergentes únicamente en lugares con mayor precipitación. Puede o no tener una capa inferior conformada generalment por hoja perenne, vegetación del suelo es escasa. 1.- Bosques Karst se caracterizan por árboles de pequeño diámetro, alta densidad de árboles y hojas cauducifolias y scleromorphy. En la base de mogotes el bosque puede ser mésico con una altura de 25 a 30 m, y un dosel cerrado de especies de hoja perenne. En las laderas y cimas la vegetación es un bosque caducifolio / bosques con árboles de 16 a 18 metros y hojas esclerófilas. En mogotes cubanos, el bosque tiene una pendiente de 10 a 16 m de altura de dosel abierto de árboles de hoja caduca con troncos de barril y abundantes cactáceas columnares, bromelias y diversas formas de arbustos y árboles esclerófilos. 2.- Presenta pequeños parches los bosques lluvioso submontano o montano (Puerto Rico menor a 600m de altitud y hasta 1100 m en las montañas kársticas). Se compone de árboles de hoja cauducifolia tolerantes a la sequía con un dosel abierto (6-8 m de altura). El estrato arbustivo es de 2-3 m de altura y muy denso. Las rocas y los troncos están cubiertos por musgos y epífitas.

Threat.Threat-description: Increasing human population can be a cause of loss of woodland distribution due to increase in resource use, expansion of infrastructure, and changes in land use. It is also indirectly associated to the spread of invasive species.
Elimination of tree cover.

Climate conditions are generally considered of great importance for the maintainance of forest vegetation and characteristic processes of several macrogroups, and were also incorporated in the process of macrogroup potential distribution modeling and validation (Bow et al. 2008; Josse et al. 2009)⁠. Thus we considered climate change as a plausible future threat of degradation of environmental conditions (Laurance & Williamson 2001; Tovar et al. 2013)⁠

⁠Defaunation is considered a large and pervasive threat to biodiversity, the loss of large vertebrates due to overexploitation has an impact in important biotic associations in ecosystems (Galetti & Dirzo 2013; Dirzo et al. 2014)⁠.

Conceptual-ecosystem-model.CEM-summary: A general conceptual model is presented graphically in Fig. S1. We include in this model the most important large scale threats to forest in the Americas: loss of forest cover due to agriculture and live stock expansion; defaunation due to hunting (or “empty forest syndrome”), structural and compositional changes due to selective logging and invasion of exotic species, changes in disturbance regimes due to land use practices and development and shifting climatic conditions due to climate change.

Distribution.Summary: Complejo Edafoxerófilo de Mogotes del Caribe (1); Bosque Montano y Submontano sobre Carso del Caribe (B) Cuba, Jamaica y Puerto rico y problamente en otras Islas del Caribe. 1.- Cuba, Republica Dominicana, Jamaica y Puerto Rico; 2.- Cuba, Jamaica y Perto Rico.
Distribution.Biogeographic-region: WWF ecoregion 'Trinidad and Tobago moist forests'

Collapse-definition.Spatial-collapse: As the tree growth form is the main structural element of any forest macrogroup, a forest macrogroup was assumed to collapse if the original woodland cover was completely replaced by a non-woodland cover, or if the tree-cover within its potential distribution declined to zero (criteria A and B).
Collapse-definition.Functional-collapse: For assessing environmental degradation under criterion C, we considered two different indicators. In the case of climate change, we assume that the ecosystem collapsed if the climatic conditions shifted from mostly suitable for the focus macrogroup, to mostly suitable to a different macrogroup. Additionally for flooded and swamp forest, we assumed ecosystem collapse if the amount of detected surface water within the potential distribution of the macrogroup declined to zero. For assessing disruption to biotic processes and interactions under criterion D we assumed that most of the fundamental processes and interactions disappeared with intensive use of woodlands under high population density. We also assumed that the ecosystem would collapse if the population of large mammals declined to less than 10% of their original population size.

Case-Study.name: Forest Macrogroups of the Americas: '1.A.1.Ea.296 - Caribbean & Mesoamerican Pine-Oak Dry Forest VU'
Case-Study.Case-Study-Name: Forest Macrogroups of the Americas: '1.A.1.Ea.296 - Caribbean & Mesoamerican Pine-Oak Dry Forest VU'

Assessment-Target.AT-description: The '1.A.1.Ea.296 - Caribbean & Mesoamerican Pine-Oak Dry Forest' is a forest macrogroup belonging to the '1.A.1.Ea Caribbeo-Mesoamerican Dry Forest' division in the International Vegetation Classification system (Faber-Langendoen et al. 2014). It is considered here as a proxy for a forest ecosystem type in a regional assessment of forest ecosystems in the Americas.

Characteristic-biota.Taxon: Cladium mariscus ssp. jamaicense (= Cladium jamaicense)

Abiotic-environment.Summary: Clima Estacional Suelos de origen volcánico, afloramientos de rocas ígneas, suelos derivados de roca basáltica y suelos latosólicos ácidos arcillosos y con presencia de cantos de grava cuarzosa, Bien drenados. (1). Los Bosques de Pino crecen en sustratos de areniscas y serpentina (3 al 7)

Biotic-processes.Summary: Parte de su extensión se ha convertido en pastos de jaragua, una graminea introducida, sabanas pastizal o plantaciones. (1)

Threat.Threat-description: Increasing human population can be a cause of loss of woodland distribution due to increase in resource use, expansion of infrastructure, and changes in land use. It is also indirectly associated to the spread of invasive species.
Elimination of tree cover.

Climate conditions are generally considered of great importance for the maintainance of forest vegetation and characteristic processes of several macrogroups, and were also incorporated in the process of macrogroup potential distribution modeling and validation (Bow et al. 2008; Josse et al. 2009)⁠. Thus we considered climate change as a plausible future threat of degradation of environmental conditions (Laurance & Williamson 2001; Tovar et al. 2013)⁠

⁠Defaunation is considered a large and pervasive threat to biodiversity, the loss of large vertebrates due to overexploitation has an impact in important biotic associations in ecosystems (Galetti & Dirzo 2013; Dirzo et al. 2014)⁠.

Conceptual-ecosystem-model.CEM-summary: A general conceptual model is presented graphically in Fig. S1. We include in this model the most important large scale threats to forest in the Americas: loss of forest cover due to agriculture and live stock expansion; defaunation due to hunting (or “empty forest syndrome”), structural and compositional changes due to selective logging and invasion of exotic species, changes in disturbance regimes due to land use practices and development and shifting climatic conditions due to climate change.

Distribution.Summary: Bsq.Seco Siempreverde: (1); Bsq. Siempreverde: (2) ; Bosque de Pino de hoja ancha: (3,4) ; Bosque de pino: (5,6,7) Vertiente del Caribe de México, Centroamerica y El Caribe. Vertiente del Caribe de México y parte de Costa Rica. (1)
Distribution.Biogeographic-region: WWF ecoregion 'Sierra de la Laguna pine-oak forests'
WWF ecoregion 'Sierra de la Laguna dry forests'
WWF ecoregion 'Trans-Mexican Volcanic Belt pine-oak forests'
WWF ecoregion 'Sierra Madre de Oaxaca pine-oak forests'
WWF ecoregion 'Sierra Madre Oriental pine-oak forests'
WWF ecoregion 'Central American Atlantic moist forests'
WWF ecoregion 'Sierra Madre de Chiapas moist forests'
WWF ecoregion 'Costa Rican seasonal moist forests'
Global 200 ecoregion 'Sierra Madre Oriental and Occidental pine-oak forests'

Collapse-definition.Spatial-collapse: As the tree growth form is the main structural element of any forest macrogroup, a forest macrogroup was assumed to collapse if the original woodland cover was completely replaced by a non-woodland cover, or if the tree-cover within its potential distribution declined to zero (criteria A and B).
Collapse-definition.Functional-collapse: For assessing environmental degradation under criterion C, we considered two different indicators. In the case of climate change, we assume that the ecosystem collapsed if the climatic conditions shifted from mostly suitable for the focus macrogroup, to mostly suitable to a different macrogroup. Additionally for flooded and swamp forest, we assumed ecosystem collapse if the amount of detected surface water within the potential distribution of the macrogroup declined to zero. For assessing disruption to biotic processes and interactions under criterion D we assumed that most of the fundamental processes and interactions disappeared with intensive use of woodlands under high population density. We also assumed that the ecosystem would collapse if the population of large mammals declined to less than 10% of their original population size.

Case-Study.name: Forest Macrogroups of the Americas: '1.A.1.Ea.561 - Caribbean & Mesoamerican Seasonal Dry Forest VU'
Case-Study.Case-Study-Name: Forest Macrogroups of the Americas: '1.A.1.Ea.561 - Caribbean & Mesoamerican Seasonal Dry Forest VU'

Assessment-Target.AT-description: The '1.A.1.Ea.561 - Caribbean & Mesoamerican Seasonal Dry Forest' is a forest macrogroup belonging to the '1.A.1.Ea Caribbeo-Mesoamerican Dry Forest' division in the International Vegetation Classification system (Faber-Langendoen et al. 2014). It is considered here as a proxy for a forest ecosystem type in a regional assessment of forest ecosystems in the Americas.

Abiotic-environment.Summary: precipitaciones anuales entre 1000 y 1500 mm,temperatura media sobre 24°C (2). clima estacionalmente seco y precipitación anual entre 1000 – 2000 mm (3) Estos sistemas ocurren en mesetas, terrazas coluviales, laderas con afloramientos rocosos y calas protegidas basáltica derivado de los suelos, o de cenizas volcánicas, o arcilloso y generalmente bien drenados.(2) . Calizas porosas o suelos superficiales sobre calizas. Hay diferencias de la profundidad del suelo que inciden en la estructura del bosque, con suelos mas delgados generando un bosque mas bajo, pero de troncos gruesos.(3)

Biotic-processes.Summary: suelos de profundidad variable, textura, y la alcalinidad, y típicamente tienen un dosel de 10-25 m de altura, cerrado en función del contenido y tipo de nutrientes de los suelos. Este sistema colinda con bosques premontanos húmedo (2). En general el bosque es de estatura baja a media, con la mayoría de las especies deciduas, algunas comunidades más cercanas a la costa se caracterizan por poseer numerosas cactáceas arborescentes (3)

Threat.Threat-description: Increasing human population can be a cause of loss of woodland distribution due to increase in resource use, expansion of infrastructure, and changes in land use. It is also indirectly associated to the spread of invasive species.
Elimination of tree cover.

Climate conditions are generally considered of great importance for the maintainance of forest vegetation and characteristic processes of several macrogroups, and were also incorporated in the process of macrogroup potential distribution modeling and validation (Bow et al. 2008; Josse et al. 2009)⁠. Thus we considered climate change as a plausible future threat of degradation of environmental conditions (Laurance & Williamson 2001; Tovar et al. 2013)⁠

⁠Defaunation is considered a large and pervasive threat to biodiversity, the loss of large vertebrates due to overexploitation has an impact in important biotic associations in ecosystems (Galetti & Dirzo 2013; Dirzo et al. 2014)⁠.

Conceptual-ecosystem-model.CEM-summary: A general conceptual model is presented graphically in Fig. S1. We include in this model the most important large scale threats to forest in the Americas: loss of forest cover due to agriculture and live stock expansion; defaunation due to hunting (or “empty forest syndrome”), structural and compositional changes due to selective logging and invasion of exotic species, changes in disturbance regimes due to land use practices and development and shifting climatic conditions due to climate change.

Distribution.Summary: Bsq. seco caducifolio estacional, Bsq.semi-deciduos. Sierra Madre Oriental, Sierra de San Carlos, Sierra de Tamaulipas, y mesetas del noreste de México (1). Valles secos de Gutemala y Honduras (2). Peninsula de Yucatan (3)
Distribution.Biogeographic-region: WWF ecoregion 'Sierra Madre Oriental pine-oak forests'
WWF ecoregion 'Central American Atlantic moist forests'
Global 200 ecoregion 'Sierra Madre Oriental and Occidental pine-oak forests'

In the case of climate change, we assume that the ecosystem collapsed if the climatic conditions shifted from mostly suitable for the focus macrogroup, to mostly suitable to a different macrogroup. Additionally for flooded and swamp forest, we assumed ecosystem collapse if the amount of detected surface water within the potential distribution of the macrogroup declined to zero. For assessing disruption to biotic processes and interactions under criterion D we assumed that most of the fundamental processes and interactions disappeared with intensive use of woodlands under high population density. We also assumed that the ecosystem would collapse if the population of large mammals declined to less than 10% of their original population size.

Case-Study.name: Forest Macrogroups of the Americas: '1.A.1.Ea.562 - Pacific Mesoamerican Seasonal Dry Forest NE'
Case-Study.Case-Study-Name: Forest Macrogroups of the Americas: '1.A.1.Ea.562 - Pacific Mesoamerican Seasonal Dry Forest NE'

Assessment-Target.AT-description: The '1.A.1.Ea.562 - Pacific Mesoamerican Seasonal Dry Forest' is a forest macrogroup belonging to the '1.A.1.Ea Caribbeo-Mesoamerican Dry Forest' division in the International Vegetation Classification system (Faber-Langendoen et al. 2014). It is considered here as a proxy for a forest ecosystem type in a regional assessment of forest ecosystems in the Americas.

Characteristic-biota.Taxon: Bursera fagaroides var. elongata (= Bursera odorata)

Abiotic-environment.Summary: La pp esta entre 1000-1600 mm/anuales. La temperatura media anual (24° C). Estacion seca de 4-6 meses del año Variable tipos de profundidad, textura y alcalinidad

Biotic-processes.Summary: De modera a alta diversidad de especies. Los arboles caducifolios tropicales son la formacion dominante.

Threat.Threat-description: Increasing human population can be a cause of loss of woodland distribution due to increase in resource use, expansion of infrastructure, and changes in land use. It is also indirectly associated to the spread of invasive species.
Elimination of tree cover.

Climate conditions are generally considered of great importance for the maintainance of forest vegetation and characteristic processes of several macrogroups, and were also incorporated in the process of macrogroup potential distribution modeling and validation (Bow et al. 2008; Josse et al. 2009)⁠. Thus we considered climate change as a plausible future threat of degradation of environmental conditions (Laurance & Williamson 2001; Tovar et al. 2013)⁠

⁠Defaunation is considered a large and pervasive threat to biodiversity, the loss of large vertebrates due to overexploitation has an impact in important biotic associations in ecosystems (Galetti & Dirzo 2013; Dirzo et al. 2014)⁠.

Conceptual-ecosystem-model.CEM-summary: A general conceptual model is presented graphically in Fig. S1. We include in this model the most important large scale threats to forest in the Americas: loss of forest cover due to agriculture and live stock expansion; defaunation due to hunting (or “empty forest syndrome”), structural and compositional changes due to selective logging and invasion of exotic species, changes in disturbance regimes due to land use practices and development and shifting climatic conditions due to climate change.

Distribution.Summary: 1. Bsq. Seco estacional caducifolio. 2. Bqs. semi-caducifolio Se distribuye desde Mexico hasta Panama. Desde el nivel del mar hasta los 1400m
Distribution.Biogeographic-region: WWF ecoregion 'Trans-Mexican Volcanic Belt pine-oak forests'
WWF ecoregion 'Sierra de la Laguna pine-oak forests'

WWF ecoregion 'Sierra Madre de Oaxaca pine-oak forests'
WWF ecoregion 'Sierra Madre Occidental pine-oak forests'
WWF ecoregion 'Sonoran-Sinaloan transition subtropical dry forest'
WWF ecoregion 'Sierra Madre Oriental pine-oak forests'

WWF ecoregion 'Costa Rican seasonal moist forests'
WWF ecoregion 'Gulf of California xeric scrub'
Global 200 ecoregion 'Sierra Madre Oriental and Occidental pine-oak forests'

Collapse-definition.Spatial-collapse: As the tree growth form is the main structural element of any forest macrogroup, a forest macrogroup was assumed to collapse if the original woodland cover was completely replaced by a non-woodland cover, or if the tree-cover within its potential distribution declined to zero (criteria A and B).
Collapse-definition.Functional-collapse: For assessing environmental degradation under criterion C, we considered two different indicators. In the case of climate change, we assume that the ecosystem collapsed if the climatic conditions shifted from mostly suitable for the focus macrogroup, to mostly suitable to a different macrogroup. Additionally for flooded and swamp forest, we assumed ecosystem collapse if the amount of detected surface water within the potential distribution of the macrogroup declined to zero. For assessing disruption to biotic processes and interactions under criterion D we assumed that most of the fundamental processes and interactions disappeared with intensive use of woodlands under high population density. We also assumed that the ecosystem would collapse if the population of large mammals declined to less than 10% of their original population size.
